Re: License #: CB820201485
Dear Mr. Smith:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 975-5060.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12503 – Policy and Procedures
Section
Description (2) The policies and procedures shall cover at least all of the
following areas:
(h) Medical, dental, and mental health care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency did not provide adequate medical support.
Investigation I interviewed Agency Director on 07/05/2023. I reported to him
that I had not yet received the requested program statement
information from Foster Care Worker 1. I asked if there was any
and Agency Director 1 stated the program statement does
address the medical/health care issue. Agency Director 1 stated
he would submit that information to me. The information
requested was received 07/05/2023 from Agency Director.
Information from the Program statement includes as follows:
Title: Medical Care
Policy: Vista Maria shall ensure that a youth in an Independent
Living program receives all necessary medical and dental care. All
medical and dental care provided shall be documented in the
youth’s record.
Health Care
Each youth will have physical and dental examinations and
treatments as needed while receiving services from Vista Maria. If
we do not get a copy of a recent physical or dental examination, a
physical or dental exam will be scheduled and completed. The ILP
Caseworker will work with the youth in gathering information about
their health conditions and any medications or treatments that are
recommended and/or provided.
IL Specialists and upstairs staff are responsible for updating
medicine information in both the soft and hard files. When
medicine is picked up from the pharmacy, either the medicine
information or the bottle should be copied and placed in both files.
2

Please Communicate All Medical Conditions and Needs
During the course of a youth’s stay, he or she may become ill or
suffer an injury, and if this occurs, the youth should tell a
responsible adult in the program right away.
The youth should notify their ILP Caseworker of any needed
medical care that is not serious to warrant urgent, emergency
room or ambulance response, but requires care. Calls to the ILP
Caseworker about emergency and urgent medical care should be
made no matter what time or day of the week.
Any youth who are experiencing medical issues and feel as
though their medical need should be addressed immediately
should contact their ILP Caseworker for guidance and if an
emergency, contact 911.
Analysis The agency does address medical/health care issues in their
program statement and handbook that is given to youth who
participate in the program as required by this rule.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code &
Section CPA Rule 400.12502 – Program Statement
Description
(1) An agency shall have and follow a current written program
statement that includes all of the following information:
(g) Medical and dental care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency did not provide adequate medical support.
Investigation I interviewed State Worker 1 by telephone on 06/02/2023. State
Worker 1 stated she interviewed Youth A at the agency on
05/22/2023. State Worker 1 stated Youth A has Type 1 diabetes
and Celiac's Disease. State Worker 1 stated Youth A reported not
receiving adequate support to appropriately address Youth A's
medical needs.
I interviewed Foster Care Worker 1 at the agency with State
Worker 1 on 06/05/2023. The supervisor for State Worker 1 also
participated by telephone. Foster Care Worker 1 stated she would
normally pick up the medications needed by Youth A from the
pharmacy and give them to Youth A or place them in the
refrigerator of Youth A's room. Foster Care Worker 1 stated she
did not know staff working with Youth A needed training regarding
3

Type 1 diabetes until Youth A had already been in placement 3
months. Foster Care Worker 1 stated Youth A would normally
notify Foster Care Worker 1 when Youth A was low on Youth A's
insulin/medications and Foster Care Worker 1 would pick them up
and give them to Youth A. Foster Care Worker 1 stated she did
not log when Youth A is given prescriptions. Foster Care Worker 1
stated the agency has a check in/out system and Youth A wasn't
doing that. Foster Care Worker 1 described Youth A as
oppositional and not wanting to be there. I asked Foster Care
Worker 1 for a copy of the agency's program statement or
policies/procedures related to medical care for participants and
Foster Care Worker 1 stated they did not have one. Note it has
been established above that the agency does have a program
statement regarding health and dental care.
I interviewed Youth A at the agency on 06/05/2023 with State
Worker 1. The supervisor for State Worker 1 also participated by
telephone. Youth A stated she was first diagnosed with diabetes in
2013 during the last 3 months of the 3rd grade. Youth A stated
she is currently doing OK but is not ready to manage her health
condition by herself. Youth A stated she had been out with her
boyfriend for about a week, and she started to run out of insulin.
Youth A stated she started to ration the insulin Youth A had and
Youth A went to Foster Care Worker 1 and Agency Nurse 1.
Youth A said Agency Nurse 1 told Youth A that Youth A would
need to take care of it herself. Youth A stated she called the
pharmacy to get a refill. Youth A said Foster Care Worker 1 told
Youth A Foster Care Worker 1 would pick it up. Youth A reported
other medications were there but not the insulin. Youth A stated
she rationed the insulin left. Youth A stated she is supposed to
get 3 boxes monthly, and Youth A needs Gluten free food. Youth
A stated her Bridge Card allowance is not enough to cover the
types of food Youth A needs due Youth A's medical conditions.
Youth A also stated she needs more help to manage her
prescription process.
I interviewed Agency Nurse 1 at the agency on 06/05/2023 with
State Worker 1 and the supervisor for State Worker 1 also
participated by telephone. Nurse 1 indicated she typically has little
or no responsibility to participants in the independent living
program regarding their medical needs. Nurse 1 reported she did
have some conversations with Youth A and attempted to help and
provide some direction to Youth A. Nurse 1 also stated the agency
does not have a program statement for the independent living
program that includes information related to medical/health care
policies and procedures.
4

I interviewed Agency Director on 07/05/2023. I reported to him
that I had not yet received the requested program statement
information from Foster Care Worker 1. I asked if there was any
and Agency Director 1 stated the program statement does
address the medical/health care issue. Agency Director 1 stated
he would submit that information to me. The information requested
was received 07/05/2023 from Agency Director.
Analysis The agency does address medical/health care issues in their
program statement and handbook that is given to youth who
participate in the program. A significant part of the expectation for
compliance is that what is presented is also what is
followed/implemented. This rule requires agency staff to follow a
current written program statement. Both staff working with Youth
A were not aware of the program statement and were not
implementing the required services for compliance.
Conclusion Violation Established

Analysis Records support that the agency was fully aware of the youth’s

knowledge the agency failed to make sure that youth had specific
food for her Youth A stated she is supposed to get 3 boxes

Youth A needs due Youth A's medical conditions. Youth A also

Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12206 – Staff qualifications
Section
Description (2) An agency’s policy on staff qualifications shall state all of the
following:
(a) A person who has unsupervised contact with children may
not have been convicted of either of the following:
(i) Child abuse or neglect.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Adequate medical support was not provided to the youth to
manage the youth's medical needs.
Investigation Interviews confirm that Youth A’s needs were not met.
Analysis State Worker 1 determined finding regarding youth’s medical
needs not being met.
Conclusion Violation Established
Technical Assistance
The Corrective Action Plan (CAP) must address specifically the steps for delivery and
administration of her insulin. Additionally, the CAP must specific how the agency will
ensure that she is able to purchase the special foods needed for her diet. Lastly the
7

agency must include in the CAP how the agency will address the special medication
and dietary needs of any youth accepted into independent living program which special
medical and dietary needs. It is strongly suggested that the agency involve the nurse for
the CCI program in working with these youth.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
